div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: HOw excellent and how innocent the art of Husbandry is, has been ≈øufficiently made out by the be≈øt of Authors; God him≈øelf, who cho≈øe out that employment for the be≈øt of the Creatures, Man, whom he placed in Eden, not only to enjoy, but to labour, without both which no place can be a Paradi≈øe. Perpetual enjoyments without bodily exerci≈øe breeding nothing but loathing and di≈øea≈øes; For which cau≈øe the actions of body or mind are called Recreations, as carrying on the grand de≈øign of God him≈øelf.

Nor can there be found in Nature a more ingenuous, nece≈ø≈øary, delightfull, or honourable employment, than Agriculture; a Calling born with us, and bred in us, affording matter for the mo≈øt
refined Wits, without which Mankind cannot be pre≈øerved; by which we are both ≈øu≈øtained and delighted. An Art wherein renowned Scholars have employed their parts, and Princes without di≈øhonour their time and pains.

Yet ≈øuch is the pride and folly of our Nation, that mo≈øt a≈øpire to collateral Vocations, which owe their life and ≈øu≈øtenance to the Husband-man, and con≈øi≈øt only in over-reaching each other. And ≈øcarce any are left to ≈øtudy the Georgicks, but ≈øuch as can do nothing el≈øe. For which cau≈øe our Ance≈øtors have left the rules and ob≈øervations by which our skill herein ≈øhould be improved only by tradition, except Virgil and ≈øome others, who have eternized their names by tran≈ømitting to po≈øterity their knowledge herein.

For the promotion of which great and needfull work our ingenuous Author hath expo≈øed his Ob≈øervations and Experiences to the publick view, which have long been ≈ømothered in private
hands, till by the good nature of a Publick-≈øpirited Gentleman, (to who≈øe indu≈øtry in ≈øeveral other things our Age is obliged) they have ble≈øt our eyes.

Embrace this opportunity, and reduce the≈øe Precepts to practice: England affords Land enough for the Inhabitants, and if men did but indu≈øtriou≈øly and skilfully improve and manure it, we need not go to Jamaica for new plantations. Farewell.

div.head: Chap. 1. Of Improvement of ground by Rabbits.
div.p:
IT is in Husbandry, as in other practical Profe≈ø≈øions, Art, Indu≈øtry, and Experience adde every day new ≈øupplies to the better, either by contracting the charge, and then the improvement is in the Method, or by multiplying
the advantage, and then it is in the increa≈øe. How many rare ≈øecrets are there now di≈øcovered, whereby the Publick is enriched, whereof our Fore-fathers never dreamed? and ≈øome doubtle≈øs are as yet concealed from us, being left to po≈øterity and the next age to find out.

Becau≈øe among≈øt many others relating to Husbandry ≈øome are of more excellent u≈øe, I have here made a ≈øelect choyce of them, reporting nothing but what ob≈øervation and experience, to which my Genius hath been long addicted, have found certainly true.
And fir≈øt I ≈øhall begin with the improvement of ground by Rabbits.

There is to be taken five hundred acres of ground within fifteen miles of London, for eight ≈øhillings the acre, which being ≈øtored with twenty Rabbits per acre, highly bred, ≈øixteen of them being Breeders, cacording to direction, will in all
probability afford either of them twelve Rabbits at three litters. I have known tho≈øe ≈øo bred, that one Rabbit hath brought at one litter ≈øometimes ten, and commonly eleven, and hath brought them up very well, and fat, and at a Lords ground I have known the like increa≈øe, be≈øides tho≈øe of my own whereof I have had ≈øufficient experience; admit ≈øixteen Rabbits bring either of them but ten at three litters, they come to one hundred and ≈øixty Rabbits, for the which after ≈øix weeks of age I know a Poulterer that giveth eight pence the Rabbit, and con≈øtantly untill Michaelmas, and ≈øome Poulterers more after Michaelmas, which may be ≈øold ≈øo then between one ≈øhilling and one ≈øhilling eight pence the Rabbit; admit them but at eight pence the Rabbit all the year, one hundred and ≈øixty Rabbits come to five pound, ≈øix ≈øhillings, and eight pence the acre, and I am
confident that in grounds not proper for them, they brought the la≈øt un≈øea≈øonable years before this, four, five, and ≈øeven at three litters. I have been ≈øufficiently re≈øolved in this de≈øign by the mo≈øt of the Warreners throughout England, though I needed not their judgement.

In five hundred acres at five pound, ≈øix ≈øhillings, eight pence per acre, to be con≈øidered the herbage for ≈øheep and other cattel at lea≈øt one hundred pound per annum, be≈øides the keeping of Poultery, Phea≈øants, Partridge and other fowl, with Pigeons, Bees, &c. and places for divers other plantations at twenty, thirty, forty, fifty pound an acre profit per annum and upward, with fi≈øh-ponds accordingly ≈øtored; be≈øides, there is an other profit in this de≈øign very con≈øiderable, and of no ≈ømall con≈øequence, with hou≈øekeeping compleat for all occa≈øions, and great conveniency for a Dairy, and very conveniently near London.

Sum total, two thou≈øand, ≈øeven hundred, ≈øixty and ≈øix pound, rent for the ground, two hundred pound ≈øalaries ≈øixty, five pound food for the Rabbits, in Hutches one hundred pound, admit though more than needs by far, being there are now better preventions than formerly, one thou≈øand Rabbits at eight pence the Rabbit three hundred thirty three pounds, total ≈øix hundred ninety eight pounds, de claro two thou≈øand ≈øixty five pounds. If the number of the Rabbits be thought too high, and the ca≈øualties too low that followeth, to make up all, and to ob≈øtruct all objections, the fir≈øt litter will breed the ≈øame year, being rightly bred and di≈øpo≈øed of, allow three of the la≈øt litters from every one of the fir≈øt breeders (the Buck being fir≈øt de≈øtroyed) bring ten Rabbits, which come to one hundred and ≈øixty Rabbits per acre, and amount unto five pounds, ≈øix ≈øhillings, eight pence
per acre, total ≈øix hundred ≈øixty and ≈øix pounds as before.

There are two Gentlemen now in London of great ability and repute, that will ju≈øtifie the≈øe proportions, and that they made out of two ≈øeveral five acres of ground either of them at lea≈øt ten pounds an acre per annum.
That there is to be taken fifteen hundred acres, for one ≈øhilling per acre, that will after the like proportion, according to the number of acres, bring many thou≈øand pounds more.
That two thou≈øand acres may be had at the ≈øame rate, that will very near render the ≈øame emolument according to the number of the acres, the ≈øame I leave to con≈øideration.

It matters not whether the ground afford any gra≈øs at all in a manner, ≈øo it be warm and dry, being there are ≈øeveral waies to feed
them, as formerly I have done, with very little charge, which will pre≈øerve them very high, and make them breed extraordinarily, and maintain more Rabbits by half than any Warren in England was ever known to do, they having totally neglected, and never ordered the right ways, Rabbits being of the mo≈øt profitable creatures of England rightly u≈øed, the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of food that may be provided for them being not con≈øiderable, as may be perceived hereafter, the later they are kept the better are the Rabbits, and the richer the fur.

I have known five hundred Breeders kept at a time in an hou≈øe, as may be within the 500 acres in Hutches, which would bring ≈øeven, eight, nine, or ten at a litter, but accounting only five at a litter one with another, being I formerly have de≈øtroyed the re≈øt, they are compleated to two thou≈øand five hundred
Rabbits per Month, and in ten Months per annum twenty five thou≈øand, which at eight pence a Rabbit comes to about eight hundred thirty and three pounds, the charge indifferent, and with the ≈øame charge doubled, one thou≈øand Breeders may be kept, and they probably amount to one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred ≈øixty and ≈øix, the Rabbits in the hou≈øe we turn out at liberty to go out and come in when they plea≈øe.

At a Months age, and at ≈øix weeks of age, when they ≈øhall be doubtle≈øs exceeding fat with ≈øuch food as ≈øhall be ea≈øily provided for them, they are then at the di≈øpo≈øe of the Poulterer, only ≈øuch as are pre≈øerved e≈øpecially for ≈øtore.
It. A ≈øort of Rabbits to be had, their fur beingworth near 3 s. 4 d. the skin, and in goodne≈øs near Bever, which I am confident may be made very near equal to Bever.

That upon tryal I found the difference between the weight of the ordinary Rabbits u≈øually in Warrens, and the breed which may be provided otherwi≈øe, to be half in half, be≈øides the great difference in the goodne≈øs of them.

If the ground want Covert ≈øhelter, or be too naked, they may be made warmer by ≈øowing French furze ≈øeeds, which will grow very ≈øpacious and to great flockt bodies in few years, and will pro≈øper very well here in England, and extend to great profit yearly; there may be Malt made within the hou≈øing belonging to the five hundred acres, that with other emoluments may ≈øufficiently advance five hundred pounds per annum, beyond exceptions, by a di≈øcreet and provident way of buying Barley at the be≈øt hand, and by the di≈øpo≈øing of the Malt, both in making and ≈øelling thereof, there being great plenty of
the be≈øt fewel therefore being fearn.
There may be many Swine kept within the compa≈øs, and ≈øeveral ≈øorts of food to pre≈øerve and fatten them not con≈øiderable.

Item Gee≈øe, Turkeys, Ducks that will lay two egges a day throughout the year, Phea≈øants, Partridges, Coots, and all other ≈øorts of Fowl kept with ≈øuch ≈øeveral whol≈øome foods, ≈øo ea≈øily prepared, and ≈øo little charge, the benefit may be made of them may ari≈øe to be exceeding great.
And for Bees, being a place ≈øo convenient, the profit of them may be maintainable under God, one hundred pounds per annum.
Item Pigeons, &c.
And for the too much neglected Creature the Silk vorm, whereas there are divers at this time that make a very great profit of them in a very high degree.

I am confidently a≈ø≈øured, that by them may be (only in one room) advanced 500 pounds per annum and upwards; whereas the only cau≈øe of not keeping them more plentifully is for want of Mulberry leaves, the Trees whereof may be planted here with the ≈øtocks and branches thereof being brought for the mo≈øt part beyond the Seas, which are dear, and mo≈øt commonly ≈øpoyled with bringing.

There is a leaf lately di≈øcovered growing here in England, and to be pre≈øerved con≈øtantly in every Garden, that doth and hath maintained them better by far than the other leaves, which will likewi≈øe co≈øt nothing, being that the ground in the five hundred acres may be ju≈øtifiably advanced to above twenty, thirty, forty, fifty pounds an acre, per annum, as may appear by the ≈øeveral di≈øcoveries at large, as followeth in the other papers. When you would have
Rabbits fat to the de≈øire, geld the Bucks that you intend to ≈ølaughter, which the Warrener may ea≈øily do, turn them out a while longer, and they will exceed in fatne≈øs, and eat more plea≈øantly by far, than otherwi≈øe.
The fir≈øt breed, charges and contingencies allowed may probably come to as before ≈øpecified, two thou≈øand, ≈øixty and eight pounds.
The ≈øecond breed, allowing ≈øome abatement for charges, comes to two thou≈øand ≈øix hundred ≈øixty and ≈øix pounds.
Item Rabbits in Hutches, charges to be abated, 1 thou≈øand ≈øix hundred ≈øixty and ≈øix pounds.
Malt per annum, five hundred pounds.
Benefit of fearn, furze, and other. fewel, five hundred pounds.
Swine, fowl, &c. two hundred pounds.
Bees, &c. one hundred pounds.
Silk worms, five hundred pounds.
All the≈øe I ca≈øt in to make up the fir≈øt de≈øign, with two hundred pounds to advance two thou≈øand pounds per annum.

div.head: Chap. 2. An undeniable proportion of Coles to be had from the Pits near Notingham to the Trents ≈øide, and ≈øo by Boats to Newark and the Towns adjacent, with the benefit may apparently accrew thereby beyond contradiction.
div.p:
FIve double Waggons and five Boats to convey to Newark down the Trent eight thou≈øand loads per annum, for which they have paid at the pits five ≈øhillings the load: and
whereas they pay commonly nine ≈øhillings and upwards the hundred mo≈øt part of the year, and much under weight, and but ≈øixteen, ≈øeventeen, or eighteen hundred weight to the load, which ≈øhould be twenty hundred weight, being a mi≈øerable griping to the poorer ≈øort of people, to allow them con≈øtantly at ≈øix pence the hundred, being ten ≈øhillings the load, will be a very great publique good, and an Act of charity in the undertakers, and will render much honor to them, together with the prayers of the poor, &c.
The eight thou≈øand loads at five ≈øhillings the load benefit, comes to two thou≈øand pounds carriage, by the return of Boats, at the lea≈øt three hundred pounds.

It. five hundred weight overplus which are to he had at the Pits by agreement, allowing two hundred thereof wa≈øte, ≈øix hundred pounds, total two thou≈øand, nine
hundred pounds.

That with a rea≈øonable ≈øum depo≈øited to have the Coals delivered at two ≈øhillings ≈øix pence per load, the re≈øt amounting to one thou≈øand pound de claro di≈øbur≈øements for hor≈øes, wains, and boats, being the ≈øtanding ≈øtock, upon con≈øiderable computations, five hundred pounds or there abouts.

Charges for hor≈øes, ≈øervants, &c. per annum under ≈øeven hundred pounds, which will be defrayed by the week, though deducted there remains de claro be≈øides the one thou≈øand pounds, two thou≈øand two hundred pounds.
If Coals be rai≈øed to a higher price at the Pits than formerly, then the Hundreds and Loads mu≈øt be ≈øold dearer at Newark, &c. and the ≈øame profit will remain.

There are divers other benefits to
be in≈øtanced and added to this de≈øign too tedious to ≈øpecifie, amounting to above one thou≈øand pounds per annum, and ≈øufficiently maintainable.

div.head: Chap. 3. Concerning Turnips.
div.p:
A Gentleman not far from London having dealt for ≈øtore of ground, part whereof being a meer dry ≈øand, and over-grown with mo≈øs, that it was not worth two ≈øhillings the acre, I advi≈øed him to cau≈øe a cutting-Knife to be made according to a new devi≈øed way, wherwith with more conveniency than
formerly they pare up ≈øuch ≈øour ru≈øhy ground as they lately farm &c. and call it Devon≈øhire Land and a Workman ≈øet about it he cut this ground ≈øome two inches thick, and turned it up, and layd the in≈øide outwards that done, letting the ground dry for the ≈øpace of a week, being formerly good neither for corn nor gra≈øs, the Workman with a ≈øtrong Iron rake raked the ground all over, then ca≈øt it over with Turnip-≈øeeds, and raked it over again, which came up ≈øo well, the leaves and roots did ≈øo well rot, cool, mellow, and meliorate the ground, that the year following and after the crop of Turnips there came very good gra≈øs.

The ground being afterwards fit for corn or gra≈øs, part of which ground he again ≈øowed with Turnips the ≈øame year, and had two very great crops, and made at lea≈øt thirty pounds an acre thereof; be≈øides as I came to him he received
10 s. an acre for the leaves only being from the very tops of the bindings, when they are bound up in bundles, and for the other part of the bindings, he ≈øelling the Turnips by mea≈øure, made at the lea≈øt twen≈øhillings the acre, wherewith they now feed their milch Cattel, which they having plenty thereof will cau≈øe them to give milk three times a day with full ve≈ø≈øels, and con≈øtantly throughout the year, and better milk by far than any other, and although the roots may be ≈øold in mo≈øt places as dear, as near London, and with the ≈øame benefit, yet the commodity of them is ≈øo exceeding great being known, they will not be parted with by any, for they are excellent for all ≈øorts of Cattel, and will feed them very fat in a ≈øhort time, and will likewi≈øe feed Calves and Lambs very fat, be≈øides, they being boyled will feed Swine to the height of fatne≈øs in a fortnights ≈øpace, and the liquor wherein they
are boyled will feed them better than the be≈øt whey. And I have ≈øeen Cows exceedingly greedy for the liquor and the Turnips boyled, they have eat and drunk of them continually, and without any other food, have afforded Milk in aboundance more than with any other food what≈øoever, and became likewi≈øe fat therewith; the Turnips boyled will feed all ≈øorts of Poultty fat, and cau≈øe them to lay their egges con≈øtantly without any corn at all, whereby may be kept both Gee≈øe, Turkeys, Phea≈øants, Partridges, Coots, Moor-cocks, in abundance without any charge, ≈øo that 'tis clear Turnips will grow on the meane≈øt ground with little labor, & without muck. I have known tho≈øe that have kept their hor≈øes fat by ≈ølicing them & ≈øo ca≈øting them into the Manger, and of all food what≈øoever there is nothing ≈øo whole≈øom and ≈øo healthfull as they be for Cattel, &c. for thereby may be avoided the Murrain
& all other dangerous di≈øea≈øes.

There is a Knight row in this City that did pre≈øerve and keep all ≈øorts of Poultry (and Rabbits) by a pa≈øte as followeth, which was made of Bea≈øts liver, the cour≈øe≈øt la≈øt corn ground and bran, with a competent commixture: but I have formerly left out the Liver, and made a pa≈øte with the re≈øt compounded with Turnips: but I found in conclu≈øion Turnips of them≈øelves is the only food both for Cattel, Swine, and Poultry. Probatum e≈øt.

The Swine being kept in an Orchard con≈øtantly bearing, the ground will fructifie the Fruit-trees exceedingly, and make them yield great ≈øtore of fruit yearly larger than formerly, and they need no other food than this Liquor, without the roots, or they may be kept up in a hou≈øe with it con≈øtantly.

There was a Gentleman well known, that would cau≈øe his Servants ≈øometimes to ≈øcatter on the
ground ≈øome ≈ømall ≈øtore of Tares, and the Swine by taking pains to get them would drink the oftner of the Liquor, and be fat the ≈øooner. I have known milch Cows kept con≈øtantly in a Yard, and never fed with any thing but Turnips, wherby a man might ≈øoon inrich him≈øelf, and having place convenient for Poultry, &c. this may appear to be as thriving for them as corn.

Turnips likewi≈øe boyled and mingled with bran will feed Hunting dogs very highly without any other relief. About ≈øeven years ≈øince I cau≈øed a woman here in London to buy a peck of meal, and to divide it into two parts, in the one, I advi≈øed her to put a peny-worth of Turnips boyled, and work it and knead it by it ≈øelf, and the two parcels being baked, the Meal that had the Turuips in, that proved to be the better bread by far, and whiter, & every way more plea≈øant to the eye, & more tooth≈øom; it is in the judgement
of mo≈øt Phy≈øicians very healthfull; be≈øides, it cuts far better than the other, and will la≈øt as long again very moi≈øt, the parcel that had the Turnips in it was in weight above five pounds more than the other, and what advantage might redound hereby to publique and private families it may ea≈øily re≈øult, when they may keep both Cattel, Swine, and Poultry, with little or no charge.

There is as much difference almo≈øt in the roots as is in Apples, therefore care is to be had in the ≈øeed; there are tho≈øe which are called Hackney Turnips, which far exceed all other, e≈øpecially for bread, & that ≈øeed may be had as cheap as the other; a pa≈øte likewi≈øe might be made with turnips to continue long, which all Poultry would like very well of, and excellent Hor≈øe-bread might be made of it, being otherwi≈øe u≈øed thereunto; all ≈øorts of Cattel and Poultry wil take ≈øufficient
without further trouble, the pa≈øte will be excellent u≈øefull food for Rabbits both in over-≈øtored Warrens, and likewi≈øe when they are pre≈øerved with other moi≈øt meats, as you may under≈øtand hereafter.

Turnips will afford two very good crops in one year, and the crops of them are worth to be ≈øold thirty pounds an acre, as will be confirmed: be≈øides, ≈øome ground they will in my knowledge afford a 3d. crop the ≈øame year, & although the roots of the la≈øt crop come not to full maturity, yet the roots and leaves being ≈øuffered to grow thicker without cutting, or pulling, will be better at the pre≈øent than an acre of the be≈øt Gra≈øs, and compa≈øs of ground where a ≈øheaf of Wheat doth grow which yieldeth a ≈ømall quantity of wheat, it will afford one hundred of Turnips, near two hundred, ≈øo that the profit of two crops thereof will far tran≈øcend the profit
of the wheat, and the charge of the wheat far greater ordinarily.
Turnips may be ≈øown in heathy ground at the fir≈øt breaking up, and ≈øome have ≈øowed them immediatly after rye, flax, and e≈øpecially after pea≈øe.

div.head: Chap. 4. Of Sow-Thi≈øtles.
div.p:
ONe ≈øleight plowing and harrowing, or but rai≈øing the round in the lea≈øt kind to have two crops in one year proportionably to the fruitfulle≈øt gra≈øs, and ≈øo con≈øtantly every year without any further trouble, or charge at all, which is ≈øo wonderfully fruitfull for milch Cows that be≈øides

It hath been ob≈øerved formerly, that when Sows could not maintain their Pigs for want of milk, the Country people would find out the≈øe Sow-thi≈øtles which would exceedingly advantage them for the increa≈øe of their Milk; and I have known the like performed by Rabbits in a very ≈øtrange manner: whil≈øt the Thi≈øtles are young they willmaintain Calves, Lambs, Pigs, &c. which you may wean, and rai≈øe to the highe≈øt perfection without any other food; when they be come old and ≈øeedy, Cattel will eat only the tops, and therefore the oftner you cut themthemore u≈øefull they are; when the down is upon them ready to flye, then gather the ≈øeeds when the Sun is up, the ≈øeed being dry you may find ≈øufficient
of them in Corn-fields & upon Ditches where Cattel cannot come at them; the benefit might be made ≈øo great thereof, that the worth cannot be with brevity expre≈øt.

div.head: Chap. 5. Of Clover-gra≈ø.
div.p:
ONe Sir Richard We≈øton, hath a think between thirty and forty acres, about ten acres thereof he ≈øowed this year with Barly, which Barly being in cutting, and proved ≈øo great, adjudged worth ten pound an acre, he feared it might hinder the Clover-gra≈øs, notnotwith≈øtanding we viewing it narrowly
did perceive the gra≈øs, much of it, as it were begining to look out of the ground, the which leaves were not bigger than an Onion, which yet Sir Richard was glad to ≈øee, he intends that nothing comes in that untill Michaelmas, and by that time he hopes e≈øpecially with a good ≈øhower, ≈øoon after the Barly is taken off, it will cover the ground: the la≈øt year he ≈øowed two Fields, each about eight acres, one with Flanders ≈øeed, the other with his own in the Husks, the former was ≈øo fair upon the ground at the felling in mid May la≈øt, that he prote≈øted he would not have taken ten pound for the ≈øeed only he expected therefrom, neverthele≈øs the Summers draught e≈øpecially ≈øoon after the cutting, before it could get head again to ≈øhade it ≈øelf, and the ground ≈øo ≈øcorchd it together, with his hopes, at length be re≈øolved to feed his Cattel with, and re≈øerve for ≈øeed the Cotten clo≈øe being colder &
a moy≈øter ≈øoyl, and thereupon the better enduring the heat, which otherwi≈øe he made far le≈øs e≈øteem of, becau≈øe it came up unevenly or in Banks like Mr. Houghtons, or rather wor≈øe, which I conceive was to be attributed partly to the wetne≈øs, but perhaps chiefly the ≈øeeds in the Husks, which could not be but unequal experience, ≈øhewing that ≈øome of the Husks are empty, others full; Sir Richard him≈øelf told me, that he had found eight ≈øcore ≈øeeds as I remember he ≈øaid, or at lea≈øt eighty I am ≈øure he ≈øaid, in one head, and then he re≈øolved to cut it, and becau≈øe hay is dear in tho≈øe parts this year, near three pound a load, Sir Richard told me he ≈øold it near that rate one hundred and fifty Loads of his extraordinary hay, which his meadows watered with his new River, and thereby continuing the draught did yield he intends to get off the head of the gra≈øs, as he doth tho≈øe of the Flax, and dry them in the Sun to
get out the ≈øeed more ea≈øily, and withall to ≈øave his hay: for he ≈øays that when once he can get ≈øufficient ≈øeed of his own, he ≈øhall then, and not before then be Ma≈øter of the work, for he ≈øu≈øpects ≈øophi≈øtication of the out-landi≈øh ≈øeed, that it is mixed with old, and ≈øome not fully ripe baked in Ovens, the ea≈øier to make it unhusk it ≈øelf; for the manner of ≈øowing of it he having experimented divers wayes finds the be≈øt peece that ever he had to be ≈øowed alone without any other grain for the time, the beginning of the mid April is the be≈øt, and therefore he would advice Mr. Houghton not to venture his Summer fallow at Autumn, unle≈øs it be a little quantity to make experiment; be≈øides, he did much di≈øapprove the laying ≈øheep upon it two or three nights, as he intended to do la≈øt May as ≈øoon as it was cut, becau≈øe it would prove a hinderance to the next crop, which with a
≈øhower would (as he ≈øays) in ≈øix days grow half a foot high, for the quantity of the hay it yielded two load and an half on an acre at a ≈øelling rate, for the nature of the ground that is mo≈øt proper for it, which will bear little other gra≈øs; To conclude, he findeth that the gra≈øs improves the ground, for he hath this year exceeding great buck Wheat upon a piece of heathy ground, not one ≈øhilling the acre before, which hath been Clove gra≈øs three years, for flax, he ≈øaid, that requires a dry ≈øoyl, &c. La≈øtly, he ≈øaith that at St. Foyn it is exceeding profitable, and may be cut ≈øeven or eight times in a year, but that it requires a very rich Land, and mu≈øt not be fed at all; And now I hope that my faithfull de≈øires to relate fully all that I had learned in this will plead excu≈øe for me.

div.head: Concerning E≈øperate or Clover-gra≈øs.
div.p:
THe Country where E≈øperate or Clovergra≈øs is mo≈øt in u≈øe at this day is Daphine towards the quarter of Day; It is a gra≈øs very hardy, not much inferionr to Luceran, it renders abundance of very exqui≈øite hay very great ≈øub≈øtantial and much de≈øired, proper to nouri≈øh and fatten all ≈øorts of four footed Bea≈øts, young and old Lambs, and Calves, making their Dams exceedingly to abound with milk, it al≈øo produceth ≈øeed every year, that ≈øerveth the Cattel in≈øtead of Oats, and fattens Poultry, it makes them to prove and quickly to lay egges, it will grow in a poor ≈øandy Land, and it leaves a certain fatning vertue in it for the profit of Corn being ≈øown after it, which makes it more in reque≈øt, it de≈øires not watering,
it fears the biting of the Bea≈øts, the delicacy of it draws them in ≈øuch am anner that having once ta≈øted of it they will go three leagues to feed of it, if it be not well inclo≈øed; the hay of this gra≈øs is little higher than two foot, but it is ≈øo much the thicker, it is cut three times a year, provided that the place agree with it, and that the gra≈øs be noteaten with bea≈øts, the fir≈øt time is at the end of March, the ≈øecond towards July, the la≈øt about the midle of September; the hay of the fir≈øt cuts not ≈øo great as the ≈øecond, becau≈øe that in this place it produceth ≈øeeds, and by con≈øequence it groweth bigger, this being cut, the ≈øeed is taken up like Oats, and then is thru≈øt together with the fir≈øt, expecting the la≈øt, that the≈øe three mingled togemay ≈øerve for profitable provi≈øion for the bea≈øts all the year; a Ma≈øter of a Family may be well advi≈øed to u≈øe this Husbandry, con≈øidering the notable profit which will
come to him thereby in regard of the Hay, the Oats, and the gra≈øs of the Field, he will find the ≈øeed of this exqui≈øite pa≈øture, is a thing one may well ≈øend to enquire after in Daphine although it be as far almo≈øt as the utmo≈øt of France, without fear of introducing a novelty, ≈øeeing the≈øe will ≈øo exceedingly countenance his labour, which principally he doth regard, a≈ø≈øuring him≈øelf that in what part ≈øoever of the≈øe three Countries he ≈øhall remain, this gra≈øs will profit him, for its faculty, to grow neverthele≈øs in a temperate air than in a hot, and in a land more light than heavy; and to effect this bu≈øine≈øs (I give you notice) that this ≈øeed of Clover-gra≈øs is ≈øold commonly at the double price of Oats; to plant it mu≈øt be appointed for ≈øome acres of Land; cho≈øen as afore≈øaid, not ≈øtony, becau≈øe of cutting of the gra≈øs, then it mu≈øt be in a place commodiou≈øly inclo≈øed, for the rea≈øons
afore≈øaid, and after that he hath well, and to the purpo≈øe laboured the land during Winter, the Spring approaching, at the end of February, or the beginning of March, he ≈øhall ≈øow the ≈øeeds, but very thick, it being nece≈ø≈øary four times more of that than of wheat, that it may grow to cover all the ground with the gra≈øs, without leaving place for any malignant gra≈øs, which may come to grow there, to its detriment; the flower of the land mu≈øt be well plowed, like a meadow, ≈øo that without hinderance the Sythe may go up and down freely; the fir≈øt year, this gra≈øs makes no great increa≈øe, being almo≈øt wholly imployed to take hold and ≈øtrengthen it ≈øelf, but the three years following it recompenceth the ≈ølackne≈øs, producing abundance of good hay, al≈øo all the time it ≈øtays in the ground it imyloys all the meaÃÑs to be profitable unto it, (which in times pa≈øt) it comes to nothing,
for which cau≈øe, the place where the Clover-gra≈øs grows is then converted into tillage, and by that means the ground being deep plowed produce very fair Winter and Summer corn, for three or four years. And for that you ≈øhall be accommodated with ≈øuch good pa≈øture, and fair corn with it, you ≈øhould manage this Husbandry ≈øo, that you ≈øhould alwaies have new and old Clover-gra≈øs, to make ≈øome ≈øerve for hay, and other for corn, whereby you can neither want for one nor the other. Probatum e≈øt.

div.head: The ≈øecond Experiment.
div.p:
Fir≈øt ≈øow Flax, then a crop of Turnips, and after about April following, you may ≈øow the ground with Oats, and upon Clover-gra≈øs ≈øeeds, only harrowing it with Bu≈øhes or bu≈øhed harrows, which will come up after the Oats are mowed, and will yield you a very great

div.head: Chap. 7. Of Pumpions.
div.p: THe next are Pumpions, which may be occa≈øioned to grow in the coar≈øe≈øt ground, even all ≈øtone in a manner, as followeth.

div.head: Chap. 8. Of the Roman Bean and Liquori≈øh.
div.p: THere is a Grain called by ≈øome the Roman Bean, which are excellent for Hor≈øes, Dogs, Poultry, and Swine, and will as is made apparent beyond contradiction afford above one hundred pound per acre benefit, as they may be ordered.
